title: Genetic Testing
author: R. Morgan Griffin

sections.heading: Who Gets the Test?
content: Genetic testing is an option for any woman before or during pregnancy. Sometimes the baby's father gets tested, too. Your doctor may suggest genetic testing if family history puts your baby at a higher risk of inherited diseases.

The tests you need may depend on your heritage. Certain ethnic groups have a higher risk of certain diseases. For instance, people with eastern European or Ashkenazi Jewish backgrounds have a higher risk of Tay-Sachs disease and Canavan disease . Blacks have a higher risk of sickle cell disease . Whites have a higher risk of cystic fibrosis .

content_blocks.text: Genetic testing is an option for any woman before or during pregnancy. Sometimes the baby's father gets tested, too. Your doctor may suggest genetic testing if family history puts your baby at a higher risk of inherited diseases.

The tests you need may depend on your heritage. Certain ethnic groups have a higher risk of certain diseases. For instance, people with eastern European or Ashkenazi Jewish backgrounds have a higher risk of Tay-Sachs disease and Canavan disease . Blacks have a higher risk of sickle cell disease . Whites have a higher risk of cystic fibrosis .

sections.heading: What the Test Does
content: Doctors use different types of genetic testing. Standard screenings check your baby's risk of birth defects such as Down syndrome , trisomy 18 , trisomy 13, neural tube defects, and others. Carrier tests can show if you -- or the baby's father -- carry genetic diseases. These include cystic fibrosis, Fragile X syndrome , sickle cell disease, Tay-Sachs, and others.

content_blocks.text: Doctors use different types of genetic testing. Standard screenings check your baby's risk of birth defects such as Down syndrome , trisomy 18 , trisomy 13, neural tube defects, and others. Carrier tests can show if you -- or the baby's father -- carry genetic diseases. These include cystic fibrosis, Fragile X syndrome , sickle cell disease, Tay-Sachs, and others.

sections.heading: How the Test Is Done
content: A nurse or phlebotomist will take a sample of your blood or saliva . There is no risk to you or your baby.

content_blocks.text: A nurse or phlebotomist will take a sample of your blood or saliva . There is no risk to you or your baby.

sections.heading: What to Know About the Test Results
content: Genetic tests don't diagnose your baby with a disease. They only tell you if your baby has a higher risk. Your doctor may suggest follow-up tests, such as amniocentesis or CVS, to get more information.

Testing the father can also help. Some diseases can be inherited only if both parents carry the gene. Your doctor can rule out some problems, such as Tay-Sachs, cystic fibrosis, and sickle cell anemia, if the father tests negative -- even if you test positive.

content_blocks.text: Genetic tests don't diagnose your baby with a disease. They only tell you if your baby has a higher risk. Your doctor may suggest follow-up tests, such as amniocentesis or CVS, to get more information.

Testing the father can also help. Some diseases can be inherited only if both parents carry the gene. Your doctor can rule out some problems, such as Tay-Sachs, cystic fibrosis, and sickle cell anemia, if the father tests negative -- even if you test positive.
